title: 110_hr1566
content: The Act may be cited as the "Stevie Wonder Congressional Gold Medal Act". The Congress finds Stevie Wonder, born in Saginaw, Michigan in 1950, has been a major figure in the music industry for 40 years. He became blind due to a visual condition caused by excess oxygen in an incubator. Signed by Motown Records at a young age, his first album made him a star with a number 1 hit in 1963. In 1964, Stevie Wonder recorded without the "Little" nickname. His first hit as a teenager, "Uptight (Everything's Alright)," reached number 3 on the pop charts and number 1 on the rhythm and blues charts. He co-wrote most of his singles from 1967 onwards and collaborated with Motown artists. His recording contract with Motown Records expired shortly after his 21st birthday in 1971. In 1971, Stevie Wonder's recording contract with Motown Records expired, and he returned with complete artistic control. His album "Songs in the Key of Life" in 1976 was a huge success with hits like "Sir Duke" and "I Wish". He released "Hotter Than July" in 1980, featuring the hit "Masterblaster (Jamming)". Stevie Wonder's album "Hotter Than July" included the hit single "Happy Birthday," which he used to popularize the campaign for Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday to become a national holiday. In 1981, Wonder, along with the Congressional Black Caucus and other civil rights organizations, hosted the Rally for Peace Press Conference in Washington, D.C. The first Martin Luther King Day was celebrated in 1986 with a concert headlined by Stevie Wonder, who pioneered the use of synthesizer in rhythm and blues and broadened his lyrics to address racial and spiritual concerns. In 1984, Stevie Wonder dedicated his Oscar win to Nelson Mandela, resulting in his music being banned in South Africa. In 1985, he performed on charity singles raising awareness for famine in Africa and the AIDS epidemic. Wonder released the successful album "Characters" in 1987, with the hit song "Skeletons." He returned in 1991 with a soundtrack for Spike Lee. Stevie Wonder's musical career continued with the soundtrack for Spike Lee's film "Jungle Fever" in 1991 and the album "Conversation Peace" in 1995. He won two Grammy Awards for the single "For Your Love" and released his first new album in 10 years, "A Time to Love", in 2005. Wonder has recorded over 30 Top 10 hits, won 22 Grammy Awards, and received numerous other accolades, including induction into the Rock and Roll and Songwriters Halls of Fame. Stevie Wonder has received numerous awards for his music and humanitarian efforts, including the MusiCares Person of the Year, Rhythm and Blues Foundation Pioneer Awards Lifetime Achievement, and NAACP Image Award. He is known for his social activism, supporting causes like Mothers Against Drunk Driving and the Retinitis Pigmentosa Foundation. Wonder has also raised over $150,000,000 to fight hunger through his partnership with American Express. Stevie Wonder received the Kennedy Center Honors at age 49 from President Bill Clinton in 1999, making him the youngest recipient in its history. He also received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the National Civil Rights Museum in 2006. The Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate will arrange for the presentation of a gold medal to Stevie Wonder for his musical achievements and activism. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike the medal with suitable emblems. Duplicate medals are also authorized. The Secretary is authorized to strike and sell duplicate bronze medals of the gold medal under certain regulations. The medals are considered national medals and numismatic items. Proceeds from the sale will cover the costs. SEC. 6. AUTHORITY TO USE FUND AMOUNTS; PROCEEDS OF SALE. The United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund will cover the costs of medals struck under this Act. Sales of duplicate bronze medals will be deposited back into the Fund.
